data.text: The NHS constitution sets out the values of the NHS. Within this, the constitution states that all NHS organisations must provide a comprehensive service available to all and it has a duty to each and every individual that it serves; respecting their human rights. At the same time, the Trust has a wider social duty to promote equality through the services it provides and to pay particular attention to groups or sections of society where improvements in health and life expectancy are not keeping pace with the rest of the population.

The Equality Act sets out that NHS staff have a duty not to discriminate against patients or staff and to adhere to equal opportunities and equality and human rights legislation. This, coupled with the Equality Act 2010 has led the Trust to take a global view of its approach in relation to equality and diversity and to develop a comprehensive Equality Scheme encompassing all aspects of the equality agenda.

The Trust also intends to work in partnership with the local CCGs, Staffside, Local Authorities and other stakeholders in the assessment of its services, functions and policies, in order to assess their impact, responsiveness and relevance to all sections of the community.

The Inclusion and Engagement team are required to submit reports on behalf of the Trust annually such as the Gender Pay Gap, Workforce Race Equality Standard (WRES) and the Workforce Disability Equality Standard (WDES) and to also publish associated action plans in relation to these nationally recognised metrics. Relevant Network Groups are invited to contribute and agree to Action Plans and progress against action plans is measured the EDIG (Equality Diversity and Inclusion Group). The current network groups being:

The Trust will undertake regular reviews to ensure equity and fairness of treatment of staff. The Inclusion and Engagement Team and Employee Relations Team work closely together to regularly review cases involving those staff with protected characteristics.
The Trust recognises its legal responsibilities as contained in the Equality Act 2010 and the aims of the Public Sector Equality Duty (see Appendices 1&2). The Trust will therefore:
Gather information with regard to ethnicity, gender, disability and age linking to recruitment, promotion, training, discipline, grievance and reasons for leaving;

Conduct  impact  assessments  in  relation  to  services,  functions  and  policies, regularly reviewing them to ensure that they are not adversely impacting on any groups within society and taking remedial action where necessary;
Involve  and/or  consult  with  staff  and  service  users  in  relation  to  services, functions and policies;
Report on, and publish, the results of consultations and reviews in relation to services, functions and policies.
The purpose of this document is to:
Demonstrate the Trusts commitment to equality, diversity and human rights.
Provide a framework for the Trust to meet the requirements of legislation.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Human Resources Department is responsible for maintaining records for both job applications and existing employees (as applicable), in relation to the nine protected characteristics and:
Communicating the Policy to staff, potential employees, employment agencies and the general public;
Advising managers in line with Trust Policy;
Ensuring that the policy is updated in line with all current legislation;
Providing information as required for monitoring of compliance.

The Chief Executive, along with the Chairman, Executives and Non-Executive members of the Board of Directors will have corporate responsibility for ensuring the effective implementation of this Policy throughout the Trust. The Board will ensure that an Executive Director is given special responsibility for overseeing equal opportunities within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.
Senior Staff, Executives, Heads of Department and Managers
They carry out their responsibilities in a non-discriminatory manner;
Their staff are aware of the contents of this Policy and adhere to its provisions;
They thoroughly investigate any complaints relating either to equality of opportunity or discrimination, taking disciplinary action if necessary;
They take steps to deal with incidents of discriminatory or abusive behaviour directed towards staff by fellow employees, patients, relatives and visitors;
Staff receive appropriate training in equality and diversity issues.
Staff/Employees/workers (including permanent employees, bank, agency and locum workers, students, contractors and volunteers)
All workers are expected to observe the rules of behaviour outlined within the document. In particular they are required to:
Co-operate with measures designed to foster equality of opportunity;
Not harass or discriminate against others;
Inform managers of any incidents where they consider that discrimination or harassment may have occurred.
The Associate Director of Organisational Development will be responsible for maintaining records in relation to access to training opportunities and staff going through equality training programmes.

The Trust will establish Staff Network Groups to promote engagement with staff in relation to the equality, diversity and inclusion agenda. The Diversity Network Groups will provide our staff who have a protected characteristic with a voice and network to challenge and make improvements at the Trust regarding their specific agenda. The objectives of the group are reviewed annually and progress of associated action plans is monitored.

All staff are encouraged to join Network Groups where they have a particular passion for a given agenda. The Employee Relations team are regularly updated on events and key information relating to the Trust Diversity Network Groups.

The Trust will ensure that no discrimination occurs in relation to the application of terms and conditions of service and that posts are graded fairly and consistently in line with Agenda for Change, agreed Trust processes and the principles of equal value.

If as a result of workforce monitoring, or undertaking assessments of its Services, policies or functions, the Trust finds any section of the workforce either to be under represented or suffering disadvantage it will seek to undertake lawful Positive Action in order to rectify the matter. For example, staff from ethnic minorities be found to be under represented at a senior level within the organisation, in proportion to their representation in the total workforce, the Trust will seek to identify the cause and take positive action as appropriate e.g. introduction of targeted mentoring schemes.

Working in partnership with the CCGs, local authorities and other key stakeholders, the Trust will monitor for equality consideration service issues in relations to patients using the Trust's services compared to their representation within the local community. This is in addition to the monitoring of the following:
Summary and Review of Equality Impact Assessments;
Progress against National Benchmarks such as WDES and WRES and Gender Pay Gap reporting;
The Equality Diversity and Inclusion Group.
The EDI service will on the invitation of the Head of Employee Relations be invited to support the Fair treatment panels in the review of cases that have equality dimensions.

The Trust will ensure that relevant policies, service changes and processes are subject to an Equality Impact Assessment (EIA). The EIA process will ensure that policies, practices, services and functions are as inclusive as that they can be by ensuring that:
They do not inadvertently disadvantage anyone directly affected, and
Wherever possible, they proactively advance equality, diversity and inclusion.
The process involves the analysis of information and feedback from protected groups and others. This helps us to understand the actual or potential impact of changes on these groups.
The Trust will seek to consult with the following via its established mechanisms for partnership working:

Equality and Diversity Training is included in all Inductions for new staff. This training is integral to all Trust training courses and is consistent with the Trust approach to Inclusion. The Inclusion and Engagement Team offer additional training and resources to cover a breadth of courses to further educate and prepare staff for people management and other aspects of the role they will undertake whilst working for the Trust. Courses featured include online Deaf Awareness course and Transgender Awareness course for those staff who feel they need additional learning in this area.

The Equality Delivery System (EDS) is a toolkit and framework for assessing how NHS organisations are performing with regard to equality, diversity and human rights; how they can improve; and how they get to where they want to be.
By using the EDS the Trust will be able to meet the requirements of the Equality Act 2010. The EDS is a self-assessment tool which is about:
Real people making real improvements, that can be sustained over time;
Focusing on the things that matter most for patients, communities and staff;
Emphasising genuine engagement, transparency and the effective use of evidence.

The NHS Equality Delivery System (EDS) is a framework designed to help us improve equality performance and embed equality into our mainstream business so that we can provide a better service that meets the requirements of people from diverse communities.

data.text: All EDI policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by EDIG, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve policies and procedures. Consultation will take place with Staffside and the Policy Working Group. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. Where a key project or piece of work is to be conducted which could negatively or otherwise impact on a protected characteristic group, the person in charge of this undertaking shall complete a Standard Equality Impact Assessment Tool. This document is provided in the appendix for reference purposes.
